Discover Solutions Success Pricing Resources Contact Get a Demo Login Blog Home Corporate Ladder Brewing Climbs to New Heights in Craft Beer Corporate Ladder Brewing Climbs to New Heights in Craft Beer By: Giovanni Albanese Published: January 30, 2024 Wearing a suit and grinding it out with a nine-to-five, Monday-to-Friday schedule is only for some. Punching your timecard and answering to The Man for eight hours until the glorious moment you punch out for the day is daunting. Doing that day in and day out can certainly take a toll on the psyche and overall morale. Corporate Ladder Brewing asks the question: Why not stick it to The Man? The Palmetto, Florida-based brewery takes this quite literally, with their rags story turning to riches in just a few short years. We chatted with the co-founder of Corporate Ladder, one of our most successful Ollie partners, to hear their story of bucking the corporate grind and turning a passion for beer into a growing, award-winning brewery. (Above photography courtesy of Corporate Ladder Brewing Company) What We‚Äôll Cover in This Piece: What Is the Corporate Ladder Origin Story? Where Does the Name ‚ÄòCorporate Ladder‚Äô Come From? What Is the Brewing Ethos of Corporate Ladder? What Are Corporate Ladder‚Äôs Core and Hype Beers? Which Beer Brings Corporate Ladder the Most Pride? What‚Äôs Next for Corporate Ladder? Œî What Is the Corporate Ladder Origin Story? Corporate Ladder Brewing Company Co-Founders Blake Kleppe (on the left) and James Herrholz (on the right) | Photography courtesy of Corporate Ladder Brewing Company Founded in the spring of 2018 by Blake Kleppe, Corporate Ladder represents Kleppe‚Äôs jump from corporate to community. ‚ÄúCorporate Ladder Brewing Company is the fire inside all of us yearning to break free from the norm, to chase your passion and abandon the nine to five,‚Äù the company‚Äôs website explains. ‚ÄúEach beer is dedicated to forgetting every cubicle you‚Äôve ever sat in and to every boss who just didn‚Äôt quite get it.‚Äù In 2019, Co-Owner James Herrholz joined the culinary-inspired brewery. ‚ÄúWe do a variety of different hazy IPAs using different hops, fruited sours , lagers, stouts ,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúWe do different beers across different styles while keeping the finger on the pulse of the market.‚Äù The brewery sits in a 2,400-square-foot building, which includes a taproom and seating in the front of the house, with the back of the house featuring a five-barrel, two-vessel hot side system, a canning line, a ten-barrel Brite, a five-barrel Brite, six ten-barrel fermenters, four five-barrel fermenters, and some cold room storage, Herrholz explains. Each beer is dedicated to forgetting every cubicle you‚Äôve ever sat in and to every boss who just didn‚Äôt quite get it. Corporate Ladder Brewing Company - Blake Kleppe Recently, the company did a remodel. ‚ÄúWe lost some seating but gained perceptive space,‚Äù Herrholz says, noting the taproom has forty-six seats and couches inside, as well as some outdoor seating. He says there are plans also to add a kitchen to the taproom. ‚ÄúIf we can, we will. If not, we will look elsewhere to add one.‚Äù Return to top Where Does the Name ‚ÄòCorporate Ladder‚Äô Come From? Photography courtesy of Corporate Ladder Brewing Company ‚ÄúIt was an excuse for Blake to run away from the corporate world, where he did insurance and finance,‚Äù Herrholz says. In addition to the remodel at the Palmetto taproom, the company rebranded recently. ‚ÄúIn the early days, the company was hyper-specific to Blake,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúWe changed the tagline [of the company] to be more encompassing.‚Äù We wanted to change the norm. Corporate Ladder Brewing Company - James Herrholz Herrholz adds, ‚ÄúBefore the rebrand, the tagline was ‚ÄòQuit Work. Brew Beer.‚Äô Now the tagline is ‚ÄòDefy the Grind. Be Your Own Boss.‚Äô‚Äù Herrholz says the new branding effort reflects Corporate Ladder‚Äôs goal to move away from the corporate world and to own your own socially responsible place. ‚ÄúDream big, pursue passions, while avoiding poor business practices, bad management, poor pay,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúWe wanted to change the norm.‚Äù He adds, ‚ÄúWe do that by enabling our team and our customers to see that through our lens with our beers.‚Äù The rebrand coincided with the company‚Äôs personnel growth. Herrholz explains how, in the early days, it was just himself and Kleppe doing all the work, and they were stretched thin, limiting themselves. In 2021, Corporate Ladder brought on a couple of integral parts‚Äî‚Äúcornerstone pieces,‚Äù as Herrholz describes‚Äîto the team from Urban South Brewing in Houston. Justin Slanina and Angela Slanina came as a team and essentially ran the back of the house in Florida. ‚ÄúWe vibed with them a lot, and we knew we needed brewing talent to move this [company] forward,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúWe brought them on and gave them time to get acquainted with who we are and let them do what they want based on that.‚Äù Return to top What Is the Brewing Ethos of Corporate Ladder? Photography courtesy of Corporate Ladder Brewing Company ‚ÄúCreative is the biggest word for sure,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre also nostalgia-driven and make culinary-inspired beers. We hang our hat on emulating the desserts as best we can [in beer series like our most sought-after Dessert Station ]; cherry pie needs to taste like liquid cherry pie.‚Äù Herrholz says that the company also strives to make beers for everyone. ‚ÄúBeer is inclusive, and we do our best to accommodate that while being fun and creative and finding new ways to do it,‚Äù he says. Among those are beer-flavored beers, lagers, stouts, barrel-aged stouts, hoppy beers, and more. Corporate Ladder‚Äôs taproom has nineteen tap handles, and Herrholz explains how they shoot for a bunch of lagers‚Äîeight were on tap at the time of publication‚Äîas well as IPAs, stouts, and lagers, which ebb and flow with seasonality and events. They even have some nitro or beer gas faucets and side-pulls for Czech-style lagers. Return to top What Are Corporate Ladder‚Äôs Core and Hype Beers? Photography courtesy of Corporate Ladder Brewing Company Herrholz points to the brewery‚Äôs Dessert Station: Intangible as its top core beer. Inspired by a creamsicle, the 6.5% ABV gluten-free sour beer includes tangerine and vanilla. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs our most popular beer. We have made it the most of any of the fruited beer,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a nice mix of sweet and acidity from the tangerine. Not super thick, which makes it more approachable.‚Äù It‚Äôs been really fun to bring those beers to a wide audience. Corporate Ladder Brewing Company - James Herrholz Another core beer is their Paperweight Pilsner . The 5.5% ABV house lager is virtually always on tap and in cans at the taproom. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a neo-American pilsner,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúWe make it with modern hops, including Motueka and Hallertau Blanc.‚Äù Herrholz says the brewery‚Äôs hyper-beer nerds flock to their barrel-aged stouts. ‚ÄúUsually, they are culinary-inspired, but we do a cocktail-inspired Tiki series,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been really fun to bring those beers to a wide audience.‚Äù The Tiki Sour series includes a Pina Colada , Blue Hawaiian , Zombie , and Hurricane , among many others. Return to top Which Beer Brings Corporate Ladder the Most Pride? Photography courtesy of Corporate Ladder Brewing Company Without hesitation, Herrholz says it‚Äôs Board Meeting , a 14% ABV pastry stout brewed in collaboration with Bottle Logic Brewing . ‚ÄúWe finished it with toasted coconut and three different varieties of vanilla beans,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúIt is a really cool beer across the board.‚Äù No pun intended, of course! Initially aged in an Old Fitzgerald barrel for eighteen months, Board Meeting spent an additional thirteen months in a Stag barrel. ‚ÄúI love the blending process of barrel-aged beers, with different wood, different spirits,‚Äù says Herrholz. ‚ÄúThe depth is unparalleled and lends a cool drinking experience.‚Äù Board Meeting won a gold medal at the Great American Beer Festival last year in the first-ever pastry/dessert category, which Herrholz says fits Corporate Ladder. ‚ÄúThis was the height of dessert beer and barrel-aged beer,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúMarrying the two with care and effort paid off.‚Äù Corporate Ladder also won two silver medals in 2019, one for Contains Chocolate in the Chocolate Beer category and another for Dessert Station Cherry Almond Cookie in the Field Beer category. Return to top What‚Äôs Next for Corporate Ladder? Photography courtesy of Corporate Ladder Brewing Company For 2024, Corporate Ladder plans to expand with a full production facility set to open in Walstonburg, NC, about an hour east of Raleigh. The new spot will house a three-vessel, twenty-barrel system with a 10,000-square-foot warehouse space. Ultimately, Herrholz says this will allow Corporate Ladder to expand its distribution into Florida, North Carolina, and South Carolina. The Florida taproom will remain status quo, and the brewing will feature R&D operations, more or less. We want to establish ourselves in this region ... Corporate Ladder Brewing Company - James Herrholz ‚ÄúWe are taking those [core] beers away from them to let them brew up new, innovative beers,‚Äù Herrholz says. Outside of the production facility, in the short term, Herrholz will focus on opening another taproom and kitchen in North Carolina‚Äîsomewhere in the Raleigh/Durham triangle. ‚ÄúWe want to establish ourselves in this region as we make our production home here and build [and] evolve on that,‚Äù Herrholz says. ‚ÄúWe also are working with cool executive chefs to make food and cocktails that blend with what we do as a company, with that whole inclusivity and creativity as the mantra.‚Äù Return to top About The Author Giovanni Albanese Giovanni is a content writer for Next Glass, contributing to the Ollie blog. He is a writer by day and a brewer/business owner by night, owning and operating Settle Down Brewery & Taproom in Gilroy, California. Giovanni is passionate about a number of things, including history, documentaries and sports, but none more than reporting/writing and brewing beer. After receiving a radio broadcasting degree then a journalism degree from Salem State College in his home state of Massachusetts, he relocated to California in 2008. Then, his writing career kicked off ‚Äì covering sports, business, politics and more along the way ‚Äì while concurrently dabbling in home brewing. The home brewing turned pro in 2021 when he launched SDB Brewing Company. Settle Down Beer officially opened in February. Our Story ‚Äî Corporate Ladder Brewing Company 0 Skip to Content Visit Us Palmetto, FL Tap List Food Trucks Events North Carolina Events Shop Order Beer For Pickup Apparel Merch Our Story FAQs Event Reservations Contact Open Menu Close Menu Visit Us Palmetto, FL Tap List Food Trucks Events North Carolina Events Shop Order Beer For Pickup Apparel Merch Our Story FAQs Event Reservations Contact Open Menu Close Menu Folder: Visit Us Back Palmetto, FL Tap List Food Trucks Events North Carolina Events Folder: Shop Back Order Beer For Pickup Apparel Merch Our Story FAQs Event Reservations Contact Our Story Established by Blake Kleppe in May 2018, Corporate Ladder emerged with a modest 5-bbl brewhouse and taproom nestled in Palmetto, Florida. Blake was driven by a desire to distance himself from subpar business practices and the corporate landscape. He harbored a vision centered around diversity of thought, collective success, and shared experiences, all channeled through the medium of beer. In March 2019, eventual co-owner James Herrholz joined the team, infusing the venture with his unwavering passion for bold flavors. With a focus on culinary and dessert-inspired beers, Herrholz's expertise introduced a captivating dimension to the company's offerings. By integrating inventive and unconventional ingredients, these unique brews not only expanded the brewery's appeal but also resonated with a diverse and discerning audience. In a significant expansion move, Corporate Ladder secured a production facility in Walstonburg, NC, in December of 2023. Boasting a spacious 10,000 sq foot warehouse and a 20-bbl 3-vessel hot side, among other assets, we‚Äôve elevated our brewing capabilities to be able to distribute our sought-after beers to diverse markets, spanning North Carolina, South Carolina and, naturally, Florida. Dedicated to the belief that beer should be a universal pleasure, Corporate Ladder strives to cater to all tastes. Our mission is to provide a diverse array of options, ranging from meticulously crafted traditional lagers to gluten-free beers inspired by decadent desserts and contemporary hop-forward beverages. At Corporate Ladder, we ensure there's a perfect choice for every palate. Home About Working with Florida Beer News Locations Tampa Bay Orlando South Florida Jacksonville Tallahassee Florida Breweries Map Podcasts Store Contact Subscribe Florida Beer News Tampa Bay Corporate Ladder Brewing to celebrate 7 years of craft beer By mark May 27, 2025 # beer in florida # corporate ladder anniversary # corporate ladder beer # corporate ladder brewing # craft beer # florida beer # florida beer news # florida brewery # florida craft beer # palmetto beer # tampa bay beer Palmetto‚Äôs Corporate Ladder Brewing Company is celebrating seven years of making memorable and eye-popping beers just south of Tampa. On May 31st the celebration will include several new bottles of their gluten-free sours, barrel-aged stouts, and hazy IPAs ‚Äì the beers that put them on many beer enthusiasts‚Äô radar in the first place. From Corporate Ladder Brewing Company: Join us Saturday, May 31st 12pm ‚Äì 11pm to celebrate our 7 year anniversary! Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs dropping so far in package and on draft! BA Black Tusk Imperial Stout 15.5% ABV ‚Äì 500ml bottle Imperial Stout barrel aged in Heaven Hill 20 year barrels for 23 months then conditioned on Nicaragua la Misericordia from Resident Coffee, Australian & Costa Rician vanilla beans. BA Pretense of Knowledge Imperial Stout 14% ABV ‚Äì 500ml bottle Imperial Stout Aged for 30 months with a blend of Elijah Craig & Four Roses single barrel picks, then conditioned on toasted coconut & roasted hazelnuts. BA Fudge the Numbers Imperial Stout 15.5% ABV ‚Äì 500ml bottle Imperial Stout aged in Willett Family Estate 11 year barrel for 23 months then conditioned on cacao nibs & vanilla beans. Tiki Sour: Gin BA Saturn Gluten Free Sour 10% ABV ‚Äì 500ml bottle Gluten Free Tiki Sour aged in gin barrels then conditioned on passionfruit, falernum, orgeat & lemon. Dessert Station: Rum BA Sugar Coated 10% ABV ‚Äì 500ml bottle Gluten Free Dessert Beer aged in rum barrels & conditioned on rainbow fruit flavored candy, strawberry soft serve, orange & lemon. Dessert Station: Double Barrel Double Vanilla Mango Swirl 10% ABV ‚Äì 500ml bottle Gluten Free Dessert Beer aged in rum & bourbon barrels then conditioned on mango soft serve & 2x vanilla beans A Shares Intensely Hopped IPA (FKA Hoppy Ale) 8.5% ABV ‚Äì 16oz 4pk cans Intensely Hopped Double New England Hazy IPA Brewed with Citra, Citra Incognito & Riwaka hops. Going Long DIPA 8.5% ABV ‚Äì 16oz 4pk can Double New England India Pale Ale brewed with Citra, El Dorado & Rakau Hops Learn more about Corporate Ladder Brewing from co-owner James Herrholz on the BeerWise Podcast. About Corporate Ladder Brewing Founded in May of 2018 by Founder and Co-Owner Blake Kleppe, Corporate Ladder was the perfect excuse to run away as fast as we could from the corporate world. Since then, the team and company has grown exponentially, including adding eventual Co-Owner James Herrholz who brought culinary inspired beer to CLBC in March of 2019. We focus on fruited sours, adjunct stouts, barrel aged sours & stouts, hazy IPA‚Äôs & back of house favorites, lagers. We are always pushing the envelope while keeping our finger on the pulse of the market. Corporate Ladder Brewing Company is the fire inside all of us yearning to break free from the norm; to chase your passion and abandon the 9 to 5. Each beer is dedicated to forgetting every cubicle that you‚Äôve ever sat in and to every boss who just didn‚Äôt quite get it‚Ä¶ Post navigation Orlando‚Äôs Brewlando named Official Craft Beer of UCF Athletics Sarasota‚Äôs Calusa Brewing is celebrating Zote Day and there is treasure By mark Related Post Florida Beer News Fort Myers/ Naples Gainesville Jacksonville Orlando Pensacola South Florida Tallahassee Tampa Bay Tom Moench, craft beer pioneer and founder of Orange Blossom Brewing, passed away Friday mark Sep 8, 2025 Florida Beer News South Florida Tripping Animals Brewing Company is hosting Miami‚Äôs Premier Food Event October 18th mark Sep 2, 2025 Florida Beer News Tampa Bay Tampa‚Äôs Woven Water Brewing celebrates five years with beer releases and more mark Aug 29, 2025 Categories BeerWise Editorials Florida Beer News Fort Myers/ Naples Gainesville Jacksonville Orlando Pensacola Short Pours South Florida Tallahassee Tampa Bay Florida Beer News thrives because of the generous support of our sponsors. No. Unfortunately at this time in the State of Florida it‚Äôs not legal to ship beer. We are in the process off working on a direct to consumer shipping program. Corporate Ladder brings craft brewery trend to Palmetto News Sports Ticket Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals DINING Corporate Ladder brings craft brewery trend to Palmetto Jimmy Geurts jimmy.geurts@heraldtribune.com I recently wrote a guide to Sarasota-Manatee‚Äôs breweries as the craft beer trend continues to grow locally in popularity. Indeed, another brewery opened just days after I wrote it. Corporate Ladder Brewing Company at 4935 96th St. E. in Palmetto opened its doors at the end of May and held a grand opening on July 14. It‚Äôs Sarasota-Manatee‚Äôs 12th brewery, the sixth in Manatee County, and the first in Palmetto. Blake Kleppe and Krista Brooks serve as co-owners and head brewers. Formerly from New England and now residing in Parrish, Kleppe told me that he and Brooks home-brewed for several years before deciding to open the brewery. Kleppe said the name Corporate Ladder comes from jobs the two held before pursuing their passion of brewing full-time, with its logo proclaiming ‚ÄúQuit work. Brew beer.‚Äù He also wanted to create a craft beer-friendly hangout in the Palmetto area he now calls home. ‚ÄúCorporate Ladder exists because it‚Äôs a couple of us chasing the dream, chasing the passion,‚Äù Kleppe said. Looking for a free mini puzzle? Play the USA TODAY Quick Cross now. The atmosphere I visit early Saturday evening soon after the grand opening, and it looks like Kleppe‚Äôs already succeeded at his goal of creating a popular craft beer spot for Palmetto. My group of four was just able to snag a place to sit, and the bar was busy for my whole visit. Corporate Ladder‚Äôs interior design right now is simple and functional, with several tables, the bar and not much else. One of the tables held several board and card games, and I saw some customers bring a cornhole set outside to play with. There‚Äôs also picnic table seating outside nearby where the food truck was parked. As you increasingly see in breweries, the crowd was wide-ranging in ages and interests: craft beer aficionados getting growlers filled, young groups out socially for drinks and some families with kids who seemed to be there for the food truck more than anything else. The drinks Corporate Ladder‚Äôs beers can be served as half or full pours, with no flights yet when I visited. I opted for the half pours ($3 each) so I could sample more brews in my visit. Several of the beers sport business-themed names and multiple variations. For instance, there‚Äôs their Mergers & Acquisitions Berliner Weisse, which came in pineapple, cherry, mixed berry or peach and habanero treatments when I visited. I tried the last one, which provides an interesting blend of the Berliner‚Äôs sourness, the peach‚Äôs sweetness and the habanero‚Äôs spiciness. On the other hand, their Casual Friday witbier has an easygoing, approachable taste fitting its name. On the darker side, there was a tasty chocolate coconut doppelbock and a solid milk stout. Kleppe told me he plans to keep their beer options diverse, whether it‚Äôs hazy New England-style IPAs or lighter lagers. The food Like many breweries, Corporate Ladder plans to offer dining options from visiting food trucks and local restaurant partners. They already have the former, with food trucks visiting Thursday through Sunday. The food truck there when I visited was the Surly Mermaid from Tampa, offering shrimp po-boy and pulled pork sandwiches as well as conch fritters and a Fruity Pebbles-covered churro called a ‚Äúunicorn horn.‚Äù I tried the veggie muffuletta ($9), a take on the New Orleans sandwich that replaces the Italian meats with portabella, eggplant, zucchini, squash and red peppers, but keeps the olive salad and seasoning. Next door to Corporate Ladder is TK Grill, a brick-and-mortar version of Bradenton area food truck the Traveling Kitchen that plans to open in early fall . The restaurant will feature favorite items from the food truck, including Cuban sandwiches with Latin-style smoked pulled pork. Kleppe said that once TK Grill opens, they plan a partnership where you can have food delivered to the brewery or bring beer over to the restaurant. In time, I could see the plaza becoming a spot that draws not just residents from Palmetto, but Sarasota-Manatee at large. Corporate Ladder Brewing Company: 4935 96th St. E., Palmetto; 941-727-1222; facebook.com/corporateladderbrewing Have a favorite watering hole you‚Äôd like to see covered in this column?
